title: American_Top_40_1977_January_29th
description:
"American Top 40's heard coast to coast and around the world each week on great radio stations like KELI - Tulsa, Oklahoma, KYNG - Coos Bay, Oregon, and Radio Elita - Palembang Sumatra Indonesia."

American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Casey answers the question, "Which recording act in the history of the album chart has had the longest name?" Until 1972 it was, "The Baroque Ensemble of the Merseyside Mermusy Gaselshaf." Casey tells who put them in second place.	

One listener writes, "Dear Casey, Several times I've heard you refer to disappearing acts; artists whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve had one chart single that went to number one, and then were never heard from again. But I'd like to know about disappearing acts on the album chart."

There is a singer/song-writer in the countdown with his first top 40 hit who failed his high school music class. Now the same teacher who once flunked him is using his songs to teach the class!

This countdown has the most recent smash by the lady superstar who's had more top ten albums than any other female artist in the history of the charts; more than Doris Day, Aretha Franklin, or even Carole King.

One act in the countdown got their big debut on the Grouch Marx Quiz Show, right after their parents correctly answered the question, "How many prongs are on a fork?"
